org.gearvrf

Class GVRMesh

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRMesh
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    PrettyPrint

    public class GVRMesh
extends GVRHybridObject
implements PrettyPrint
    Describes an indexed triangle mesh as a set of shared vertices with integer indices for each triangle.

    Usually each mesh vertex may have a position, normal and texture coordinate. Skinned mesh vertices will also have bone weights and indices. If the mesh uses a normal map for lighting, it will have tangents and bitangents as well. These vertex components correspond to vertex attributes in the OpenGL vertex shader.

    The vertices for the mesh are stored in a GVRVertexBuffer object and the indices for the faces are in a GVRIndexBuffer object. Multiple meshes may share a single vertex or index buffer.

    When a vertex buffer is constructed, a string descriptor is supplied which describes the format of the vertices (the name and type of each vertex attribute). Once the format has been established, it cannot be subsequently changed - you cannot add new vertex attributes. You can change the vertex or index buffer associated with a mesh at any time.

    Skinned meshes have bone weights and bone indices which designate which bones affect each vertex and how much. The bones are supplied as a list of GVRBone objects which have the name of the bone and its associated matrices. The asset loader handles constructing skinned meshes and their associated bones. GearVRF keeps the bones for each mesh in a uniform buffer and skinning is performed by\ shaders on the GPU.

    See Also:
    GVRVertexBuffer, GVRIndexBuffer, GVRBone, GVRAssetLoader, GVRSkinningController

      • GVRMesh

        public GVRMesh(GVRVertexBuffer vbuffer,
               GVRIndexBuffer ibuffer)
        Construct a mesh with a specified vertex and index buffer.
        Parameters:
        vbuffer - GVRVertexBuffer with vertices for mesh.
        ibuffer - GVRIndexBuffer with indices for mesh.
        See Also:

      • GVRMesh

        public GVRMesh(GVRContext gvrContext,
               java.lang.String vertexDescriptor)
        Construct a mesh with specified vertex layout.
        Parameters:
        gvrContext - GVRContext to associate mesh with
        vertexDescriptor - string describing vertex layout. Each vertex attribute has a name and a type. The types may be "int", "float" or "mat" followed by an integer indicating vector size. Vertex Descriptor Examples:
        • float3 a_position float2 a_texcoord float3 a_normal
        • float3 a_position, int4 a_bone_indices, float4 a_bone_weights

    • Method Detail

      • getVertices

        public float[] getVertices()
        Get the 3D vertices of the mesh. Each vertex is represented as a packed float triplet:

        { x0, y0, z0, x1, y1, z1, x2, y2, z2, ... } This function retrieves the a_position vertex attribute.

        Returns:
        Array with the packed vertex data.
        See Also:
        GVRVertexBuffer.getFloatVec(String)

      • setVertices

        public void setVertices(float[] vertices)
        Sets the 3D vertices of the mesh. Each vertex is represented as a packed float triplet:

        { x0, y0, z0, x1, y1, z1, x2, y2, z2, ...} This function updates the a_position vertex attribute.

        Parameters:
        vertices - Array containing the packed vertex data.
        See Also:
        GVRVertexBuffer.setFloatArray(String, float[])

      • getVertexBuffer

        public GVRVertexBuffer getVertexBuffer()
        Get the vertex buffer object with the vertices for this mesh.

        Vertex buffers may be shared across meshes. You can change which vertex buffer a mesh uses at any time with setVertexBuffer(GVRVertexBuffer)

        See Also:
        getVertices()

      • getIndexBuffer

        public GVRIndexBuffer getIndexBuffer()
        Get the index buffer object with the face indices for this mesh.

        Index buffers may be shared across meshes. You can change which index buffer a mesh uses at any time with setIndexBuffer(GVRIndexBuffer).

        See Also:
        getIndices()

        public float[] getNormals()

        { x0, y0, z0, x1, y1, z1, x2, y2, z2, ...} This function retrieves the a_normal vertex attribute.

        Returns:
        Array with the packed normal data.

      • getTexCoords

        public float[] getTexCoords(int index)
        Retrieves a set of texture coordinates from the mesh.

        A mesh may have multiple sets of texture coordinates Each texture coordinate is represented as a packed float pair:

        { u0, v0, u1, v1, u2, v2, ...} This function retrieves the a_texcoordN vertex attribute where N is the value of the index argument.

        Parameters:
        index - 0-based index indicating which set of texture coordinates to get.
        See Also:
        getTexCoords(), GVRVertexBuffer.getFloatArray(String)

      • getTexCoords

        public float[] getTexCoords()
        Get the u,v texture coordinates for the mesh. Each texture coordinate is represented as a packed float pair:

        { u0, v0, u1, v1, u2, v2, ...} This function retrieves the a_texcoord vertex attribute.

        Returns:
        Array with the packed texture coordinate data.
        See Also:
        GVRVertexBuffer.getFloatArray(String)

      • setTexCoords

        public void setTexCoords(float[] texCoords)
        Sets the first set of texture coordinates for the mesh. Each texture coordinate is represented as a packed float pair:

        { u0, v0, u1, v1, u2, v2, ...}

        This function updates the a_texcoord vertex attribute.

        Parameters:
        texCoords - Array containing the packed texture coordinate data.
        See Also:
        GVRVertexBuffer.setFloatArray(String, float[])

      • setTexCoords

        public void setTexCoords(float[] texCoords,
                         int index)
        Populates a set of texture coordinates for the mesh.

        A mesh may have multiple sets of texture coordinates Each texture coordinate is represented as a packed float pair:

        { u0, v0, u1, v1, u2, v2, ...} This function updates the a_texcoordN vertex attribute where N is the value of the index argument.

        Parameters:
        texCoords - Array containing the packed texture coordinate data.
        index - 0-based index indicating which set of texture coordinates to update.
        See Also:
        getTexCoords(), GVRVertexBuffer.setFloatArray(String, float[])

      • getTriangles

        public char[] getTriangles()
        Get the triangle vertex indices of the mesh. The indices for each triangle are represented as a packed char triplet, where t0 is the first triangle, t1 is the second, etc.:

        { t0[0], t0[1], t0[2], t1[0], t1[1], t1[2], ...}

        Face indices may also be int. If you have specified integer indices, this function will throw an exception.

        Returns:
        char array with the packed triangle index data.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if index buffer is not char
        See Also:
        setTriangles(char[]), getIndices()

      • setTriangles

        public void setTriangles(char[] triangles)
        Sets the triangle vertex indices of the mesh. The indices for each triangle are represented as a packed char triplet, where t0 is the first triangle, t1 is the second, etc.:

        { t0[0], t0[1], t0[2], t1[0], t1[1], t1[2], ...} Indices may also be int values - see setTriangles(int[]).

        Parameters:
        triangles - char array containing the packed triangle index data.
        See Also:
        setTriangles(int[]), getTriangles()

      • setTriangles

        public void setTriangles(int[] triangles)
        Sets the triangle vertex indices of the mesh. The indices for each triangle are represented as a packed int triplet, where t0 is the first triangle, t1 is the second, etc.:

        { t0[0], t0[1], t0[2], t1[0], t1[1], t1[2], ...} Indices may also be char values - see setTriangles(char[]).

        Parameters:
        triangles - int array containing the packed triangle index data.

      • getIndices

        public int[] getIndices()
        Get the triangle vertex indices of the mesh. The indices for each triangle are represented as a packed int triplet, where t0 is the first triangle, t1 is the second, etc.:

        { t0[0], t0[1], t0[2], t1[0], t1[1], t1[2], ...}

        Face indices may also be char. If you have specified char indices, this function will throw an exception.

        Returns:
        int array with the packed triangle index data.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if index buffer is not int
        See Also:
        setTriangles(char[]), getTriangles()

      • setIndices

        public void setIndices(int[] indices)
        Sets the vertex indices of the mesh as int values.

        If no index buffer exists, a new GVRIndexBuffer is constructed with int indices. Otherwise, the existing index buffer is updated. If that index buffer has been already constructed with char indices, this function will throw an exception.

        Parameters:
        indices - int array containing the packed index data or null. If null is specified, the index buffer is destroyed and the mesh will have only vertices.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if index buffer is not int
        See Also:
        setTriangles(char[]), setIndexBuffer(GVRIndexBuffer), getIndices(), getIndexBuffer()

      • setIndices

        public void setIndices(char[] indices)
        Sets the vertex indices of the mesh as char values.

        If no index buffer exists, a new GVRIndexBuffer is constructed with char indices. Otherwise, the existing index buffer is updated. If that index buffer has been already constructed with int indices, this function will throw an exception.

        Parameters:
        indices - char array containing the packed index data or null. If null is specified, the index buffer is destroyed and the mesh will have only vertices.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if index buffer is not char
        See Also:
        setTriangles(int[]), setIndexBuffer(GVRIndexBuffer), getIndices(), getIndexBuffer()

      • setIndices

        public void setIndices(java.nio.CharBuffer indices)
        Sets the vertex indices of the mesh as char values.

        If no index buffer exists, a new GVRIndexBuffer is constructed with char indices. Otherwise, the existing index buffer is updated. If that index buffer has been already constructed with int indices, this function will throw an exception.

        Parameters:
        indices - CharBuffer containing the packed index data or null. If null is specified, the index buffer is destroyed and the mesh will have only vertices.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if index buffer is not char

      • getSphereBound

        public void getSphereBound(float[] sphere)
        Calculate a bounding sphere from the mesh vertices.
        Parameters:
        sphere - float[4] array to get center of sphere and radius; sphere[0] = center.x, sphere[1] = center.y, sphere[2] = center.z, sphere[3] = radius

      • getBoxBound

        public void getBoxBound(float[] bounds)
        Calculate a bounding box from the mesh vertices.
        Parameters:
        bounds - float[6] array to get corners of box; bounds[0,1,2] = minimum X,Y,Z and bounds[3,4,6] = maximum X,Y,Z

      • hasAttribute

        public boolean hasAttribute(java.lang.String key)
        Determine if a named attribute exists in this mesh.
        Parameters:
        key - Name of the shader attribute
        Returns:
        true if attribute exists, false if not

      • getBoundingBox

        public GVRMesh getBoundingBox()
        Constructs a mesh that contains this mesh.

        This is primarily useful with the GVRPicker, which does "ray casting" to detect which scene object you're pointing to. Ray casting is computationally expensive, and you generally want to limit the number of triangles to check. A simple quad is cheap enough, but with complex meshes you will probably want to cut search time by registering the object's bounding box, not the whole mesh.

        Returns:
        A GVRMesh of the bounding box.

      • createQuad

        public void createQuad(float width,
                       float height)
        Sets the contents of this mesh to be a quad consisting of two triangles, with the specified width and height. If the mesh descriptor allows for normals and/or texture coordinates, they are added.
        Parameters:
        width - the quad's width
        height - the quad's height

      • createQuad

        public static GVRMesh createQuad(GVRContext ctx,
                                 java.lang.String vertexDesc,
                                 float width,
                                 float height)
        Creates a mesh whose vertices describe a quad consisting of two triangles, with the specified width and height. If the vertex descriptor allows for normals and/or texture coordinates, they are added.
        Parameters:
        ctx - GVRContext to use for creating mesh.
        vertexDesc - String describing vertex format of GVRVertexBuffer
        width - the quad's width
        height - the quad's height
        Returns:
        A 2D, rectangular mesh with four vertices and two triangles

      • createCurvedMesh

        public static GVRMesh createCurvedMesh(GVRContext gvrContext,
                                       int width,
                                       int height,
                                       float centralAngle,
                                       float radius)
        A static method to generate a curved mesh along an arc. Note the width and height arguments are used only as a means to get the width:height ratio.
        Parameters:
        gvrContext - the current context
        width - a number representing the width
        height - a number representing the height
        centralAngle - the central angle of the arc
        radius - the radius of the circle
        Returns:
